awd_titl_txt: Causal Inference for Extremes via Tropical Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Monitoring and predicting extreme events such as flooding, financial collapses or engineering risks  are of huge importance to societies. However, extreme events by definition are rare and concern large, unlikely values, while traditional statistical techniques are based on averages and large numbers of observations. This project will create new, fast methodologies to uncover the causes and potential cascading failures when an extreme event hits a system, such as a river, computer network, or financial network. Concrete applications include flood risks predictions, tracing the source of contaminants in underground waterways, and modeling risks of airplanes runway overrun. This research will advance society’s ability to monitor, predict and prevent such adverse events. 


Extreme value statistics concerns the maxima of random variables and relations between the tails of distributions rather than averages and correlations. Unique challenges to this field are lack of data and lack of smoothness in the likelihood, which severely limits statistical learning and inference. Goal A of this research aims to advance causal inference for extreme value statistics with provably accurate algorithms that can handle datasets with thousands of variables and missing data.Goal B of this research aims to solve the Identification Challenge for deep neural networks with rectified linear (ReLU) activation, a difficult variant of the reverse-engineering problem. These problems are intimately connected and both will be tackled in this proposal via tropical algebraic and convex geometry. Preliminary work by the PI and co-authors on hydrology data have shown that the proposed methods achieve the state-of-the-art in the Hidden River Network, the benchmark problem in causal inference for extremes. The proposed research will advance society’s ability to monitor and predict extreme events in finance, engineering, and natural disasters. It will simultaneously advance both extreme value statistics and tropical geometry, widening their applications and create new interdisciplinary, data-driven research at their intersections.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the period from July 2023 through June 2024, this grant supported the research of Lorenzo Sadun and his collaborators on aperiodic tilings and on random graphs. This led to three papers uploaded to the arXiv, one of which is already accepted for publication, plus a fourth paper in preparation.

One of the papers is joint with undergraduate researcher Abigail Perryman and one (as yet unwritten) with undergraduate researcher William DiCarlo. In both projects, the undergraduates were intimitely involved in the research. Dr. Sadun provided some of the ideas, but mostly he provided guidance. Perryman's work led to an award-winning honors thesis. DiCarlo's work is continuing past the expiration of the grant and is helping to prepare him for graduate school in mathematics.

The two other papers are will long-time senior collaborators. The paper with Charles Radin is a big advance in a 10-year project. It took us a decade to develop the techniques needed to prove the existence of three phases in the "edge-triangle" model. Specifically, for edge and triangle densities (e,t) in three ranges, we understand the structure of typical large graphs with those densities. This is an example of "emergence", where large-scale structure emerges from small-scale interactions. 

This year, we greatly sharpened our tools and determined the typical structure in an infinite family of phases. We also developed "order parameters" that are nonzero in some phase and zero in others, thereby proving that these phases are truly different.

Finally, the paper with Baake, Gaehler and Mazac explores the "Spectre" tilings that gained worldwide attention in 2023. We show that, when it comes to dynamics, all versions of the Spectre tilings are essentially the same. We also give a precise description of the dynamics of this tiling.
